sentences.text: Legislative elections were held in South Korea on 10 April 2024. All 300 members of the National Assembly (South Korea)|National Assembly were elected, 254 from first-past-the-post South Korean Legislature Constituencies|constituencies and 46 from party-list proportional representation|proportional party lists. The two largest parties, the liberal Democratic Party (South Korea, 2015)|Democratic Party and the conservative People Power Party (South Korea)|People Power Party, once again set up Bloc party#South Korea|satellite parties to take advantage of the electoral system.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=20 February 2024 |title=Political parties in full-fledged election mode as April 10 voting nears |url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/nation/2024/05/113_369101.html |access-date=29 February 2024 |website=The Korea Times |language=en |archive-date=29 February 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240229214704/https://m.koreatimes.co.kr/pages/article.asp?newsIdx=369101 |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |title=선거일정 |url=https://www.nec.go.kr/site/nec/ex/bbs/View.do?cbIdx=1104&bcIdx=192949 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231125194511/https://www.nec.go.kr/site/nec/ex/bbs/View.do?cbIdx=1104&bcIdx=192949 |archive-date=25 November 2023 |access-date=25 November 2023 |website=National Electoral Commission}}</ref>

sentences.text: The election served as a "mid-term evaluation" for the administration of President Yoon Suk-yeol as it approached its third year. Additionally, there was significant interest in whether the ruling party could surpass the constraints of the ruling coalition, which did not secure a majority in the previous general election, and gain the necessary momentum to govern effectively during the remainder of its term.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=김 |first=연정 |date=2024-04-11 |title=[4·10 총선] 또 무너진 與…野 협조 없이 입법·예산 불가능 |url=https://www.yna.co.kr/view/AKR20240410039700001 |access-date=2024-04-21 |website=Yonhap News Agency |language=ko}}</ref>

sentences.text: The election saw opposition parties, primarily the Democratic Party (South Korea, 2015)|Democratic Party, retain their majority in the National Assembly. The new legislators had their first meeting on 30 May.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/south-korea-opposition-wins-landslide-parliamentary-vote-resounding-blow-yoon-2024-04-10/|title=Opposition win in South Korea election to deepen policy stalemate for Yoon|first1=Hyunsu|last1=Yim|first2=Jack|last2=Kim|publisher=Reuters|date=11 April 2024|accessdate=11 April 2024}}</ref>
<ref>{{cite news|url=https://en.yna.co.kr/view/PYH20240530131600315|title=1st meeting of 22nd parliament's DP lawmakers|publisher=Yonhap News Agency|date=30 May 2024|accessdate=2 June 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 28 February 2024, the ruling and opposition parties reached a consensus to redraw the electoral districts. Subsequently, the National Assembly's plenary session passed an amendment to the Public Offices Election Act, resulting in the reformation of the electoral districts. In comparison to the 21st National Assembly elections, there was an increase of one constituency, bringing the total to 254, while the seats for proportional representation decreased by one, totaling 46.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=안 |first=윤학 |date=2024-02-29 |title=[속보] 여야, 선거구획정 극적 합의..."오늘 본회의서 처리" |url=https://www.ytn.co.kr/_ln/0101_202402291206004957 |access-date=2024-04-21 |website=YTN |language=ko}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |last=김 |first=연정 |date=2024-02-29 |title=4·10총선 선거구 획정안 국회 통과…전북 대신 비례 1석 축소 |url=https://www.yna.co.kr/view/AKR20240229146100001 |access-date=2024-04-21 |website=Yonhap News Agency |language=ko}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=9 April 2024 |title=A Guide to South Korea's 2024 National Assembly Election |url=https://keia.org/the-peninsula/a-guide-to-south-koreas-2024-national-assembly-election/ |access-date=10 April 2024 |website=Korea Economic Institute of America |language=en}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |last=Seung-yeon |first=Kim |date=27 March 2024 |title=April elections campaign to kick off as parties race for crucial votes |url=https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20240327006100315 |access-date=10 April 2024 |website=Yonhap News Agency |language=en |archive-date=10 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240410202441/https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20240327006100315 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The election was held amid several political and socioeconomic issues in South Korea such as corruption, with President Yoon Suk-yeol of the People Power Party (South Korea)|People Power Party facing criticism over the handling of issues involving Kim Keon-hee|his wife and a Lee Jong-sup|former minister, and party leaders such as the Democratic Party (South Korea, 2015)|Democratic Party's Lee Jae-myung and Rebuilding Korea Party's Cho Kuk facing trials for bribery and forgery respectively, as well as rising inflation and the ongoing 2024 South Korean medical crisis|medical crisis. One major talking point was an incident on 18 March when President Yoon visited a grocery store in Seoul to check consumer prices and describing the 875-won ($0.65) price of a green onion he found as reasonable, only for it to emerge that the onions were being sold at a discount and that the true price of onions was three to four times higher. The incident led to opposition candidates bringing out green onions at campaign rallies and the hashtag #greenonions875won becoming a trending topic on social media throughout the election. In response, the National Election Commission (South Korea)|National Election Commission banned voters from bringing green onions to polling stations, citing concerns over "election interference". This was in turn, widely ridiculed and led to an increase in demand for green onion-themed merchandise.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=10 April 2024 |title=South Korea holds parliamentary elections: All you need to know |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/4/9/south-korea-holds-parliamentary-elections-all-you-need-to-know |access-date=10 April 2024 |website=Al Jazeera |language=en |archive-date=9 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240409224655/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/4/9/south-korea-holds-parliamentary-elections-all-you-need-to-know |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name="onion">{{Cite web |date=7 April 2024 |title=Green onion outcry: humble vegetable roils S. Korean vote |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240407-green-onion-outcry-humble-vegetable-roils-s-korean-vote |access-date=7 April 2024 |website=France 24 |language=en |archive-date=7 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240407091330/https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240407-green-onion-outcry-humble-vegetable-roils-s-korean-vote |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: On 27 October 2023 the Justice Party (South Korea)|Justice Party and Green Party Korea|Green Party announced their intention to form an electoral alliance and invited other left-wing parties to participate. This move was heavily criticized by Justice Party deputies Jang Hye-young and Ryu Ho-jeong, as well as former Justice Party Youth Committee Chair Kim Chang-in; all three believe that the Justice Party should form electoral alliances not by ideology, but with any "third zone" party opposed to the Democratic and People Power parties.

sentences.text: On 2 January 2024 Lee Jae-myung Attempted assassination of Lee Jae-myung|was stabbed in an assassination attempt while visiting the construction site of an airport in Gadeokdo|Gadeokdo, Busan. He was later criticised for using a sexually derogative term to describe People Power Party politician Na Kyung-won during a criticism of her pro-Japanese views.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last=Sang-Hun |first=Choe |date=1 January 2024 |title=South Korean Opposition Leader Is Stabbed |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/01/world/asia/south-korea-opposition-lee-jae-myung.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240102021703/https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/01/world/asia/south-korea-opposition-lee-jae-myung.html |archive-date=2 January 2024 |access-date=1 January 2024 |work=The New York Times}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 15 January 2024 the Green Party and Justice Party announced a left-wing election coalition called the "Green-Justice Party." On the same day, Basic Income Party leader Yong Hye-in announced a pro-Democratic Party (South Korea, 2015)|Democrat electoral coalition to counter the People Power Party.

sentences.text: Throughout the campaign the People Power Party argued that President Yoon's government has been unable to push its reform agenda forward since taking office in 2022 due to an uncooperative National Assembly (South Korea)|National Assembly controlled by the opposition, while the Democratic Party described Yoon's administration as "incompetent", accusing it of causing a socioeconomic downturn and mishandling several controversial issues. The Rebuilding Korea Party campaigned for an early end to Yoon's presidency,

references.text: <ref name="yonhap1"/> with Cho Kuk pledging to turn Yoon into "first a Lame duck (politics)|lame duck, then a dead duck".<ref>{{Cite web |date=10 April 2024 |title=South Koreans vote in election seen as test of President Yoon Suk-yeol |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/4/10/south-koreans-vote-in-election-seen-as-test-of-president-yoon-suk-yeol |access-date=10 April 2024 |website=Al Jazeera |language=en |archive-date=10 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240410030737/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/4/10/south-koreans-vote-in-election-seen-as-test-of-president-yoon-suk-yeol |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Early voting opened on 5 April and lasted until 7 April. Among those who cast their votes early were People Power Party leader Han Dong-hoon, who voted in Seoul, and Democratic Party leader Lee Jae-myung, who voted in Daejeon. At least 13.8 million voters participated in early voting,

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=5 April 2024 |title=South Koreans cast ballots in early voting for general election |url=https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20240405_13/ |access-date=5 April 2024 |website=NHK |language=en |archive-date=5 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240405141552/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20240405_13/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name="onion"/> equivalent to about 31% of the electorate.<ref name="ap2">{{Cite web |date=9 April 2024 |title=South Korea's president faces a major test in a crucial parliamentary election |url=https://apnews.com/article/south-korea-parliamentary-election-yoon-c362a024e6eff3d4a410927be00b4d0c |access-date=9 April 2024 |website=Associated Press |language=en |archive-date=9 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240409162448/https://apnews.com/article/south-korea-parliamentary-election-yoon-c362a024e6eff3d4a410927be00b4d0c |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: On election day, voting in 14,259 polling stations opened at 06:00 and closed at 18:00. Overall turnout was estimated at 67%, an increase of 0.8% from 2020 South Korean legislative election|2020, and the highest recorded for a legislative election in South Korea since 1992 South Korean legislative election|1992.

references.text: <ref name="ap2"/><ref name="yonhap1">{{Cite web |date=10 April 2024 |title=(LEAD) Voters hit the polls in parliamentary elections |url=https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20240409006051315?section=national/politics |access-date=10 April 2024 |website=Yonhap News Agency |language=en |archive-date=10 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240410022349/https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20240409006051315?section=national/politics |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=10 April 2024 |title=(6th LD) Tentative final voter turnout at 67 pct: election watchdog |url=https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20240410005651315?section=national/politics |access-date=10 April 2024 |website=Yonhap News Agency |language=en |archive-date=10 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240410124404/https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20240410005651315?section=national/politics |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{See also|List of members of the National Assembly (South Korea), 2024–2028}}
Exit polls indicated that the Democratic Party and its partner, the Democratic Alliance of Korea, would win between 168 and 197 seats in the National Assembly, while the People Power Party and its partner, the People Future Party, were expected to win between 85 and 111 seats. The Rebuilding Korea Party, which only contested proportional representation seats, was projected to win 15 seats. Democratic Party leader Lee Jae-myung was projected to keep his seat in Gyeyang B of Incheon against People Power Party candidate and former land minister Won Hee-ryong, winning 56.1% and 42.8% of the vote respectively. The Justice Party (South Korea)|Justice Party failed to win seats for the first time since its foundation in 2012.

references.text: <ref name="yonhapresult">{{Cite web |date=10 April 2024 |title=(4th LD) Opposition forecast to win landslide victory: exit polls |url=https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20240409006054315?section=national/politics |website=Yonhap News Agency |access-date=10 April 2024 |archive-date=10 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240410123546/https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20240409006054315?section=national/politics |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Among the elected candidates in proportional representation seats was Park Choong-kwon (representing the People Future Party), a North Korean defector who previously worked in the North Korean nuclear weapons programme before fleeing to the South in 2009.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=12 April 2024 |title=How a North Korean missile researcher became a South Korean MP |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c51n8w77z9wo |website=BBC |access-date=12 April 2024 |author1=Mao, Frances |author2=Han, Sangmi |archive-date=12 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240412221558/https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c51n8w77z9wo |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The election also saw the highest number of invalid votes cast for proportional representation seats since its introduction in 2004 South Korean legislative election|2004, with the National Electoral Commission tallying 1,309,931 such ballots, equivalent to 4.4% of votes cast.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=15 April 2024 |title=Number of invalid proportional votes hits all-time high in last week's elections: NEC |url=https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20240415004100315?section=national/politics |website=Yonhap News Agency |access-date=15 April 2024 |archive-date=17 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240417192008/https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20240415004100315?section=national/politics |url-status=live }}</ref>

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=10 April 2024 |title=사전투표진행상황 |url=http://info.nec.go.kr/electioninfo/electionInfo_report.xhtml |website=National Election Commission |access-date=9 April 2024 |archive-date=19 February 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219123257/http://info.nec.go.kr/electioninfo/electionInfo_report.xhtml |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Following the release of exit polls, Han Dong-hoon expressed disappointment over the People Power Party's losses in the election. Cho Kuk called the results of the Rebuilding Korea Party's campaign the "victory of the people" and said it showed the people can "no longer put up with the regression" of the Yoon administration. Cho also called on President Yoon to "apologize for the numerous misdeeds and corruption", and pledged to introduce a special investigation bill against Han Dong-hoon once the new session of the National Assembly is formed. Lee Jae-myung expressed thanks for the Democratic Party's showing, calling it "a great victory for our people", and said the party will "humbly watch the people's choices to the end".

<ref>{{Cite web |date=11 April 2024 |title=Opposition leader vows commitment to solving economic problems |url=https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20240411006200315 |website=Yonhap News Agency |access-date=11 April 2024 |archive-date=12 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240412000120/https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20240411006200315 |url-status=live|author=Cheong-mo, Yoo}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 11 April Prime Minister Han Duck-soo, presidential chief of staff Lee Kwan-sup, and other senior presidential advisers, with the exception of those in charge of security issues, offered their resignations to Yoon, who pledged to "humbly uphold" the election result and focus on improving the economy and reforming state affairs. In a separate statement, Han Dong-hoon also resigned as head of the People Power Party and took responsibility for its defeat in the election. That same day, Justice Party (South Korea)|Green-Justice leader Sim Sang-jung announced her retirement from politics. Sim, who ran twice for president in 2017 and 2021, was a four-term lawmaker under various minor left-wing parties. In her announcement, Sim assumed responsibility for the party losing all six seats and falling below the 3% required for proportional representation.

<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.hani.co.kr/arti/politics/election/1136197.html |title=심상정 정계 은퇴 선언 "통절한 마음으로 사죄드린다" |date=11 April 2024 |access-date=14 April 2024 |archive-date=14 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240414183047/https://www.hani.co.kr/arti/politics/election/1136197.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: In his first public remarks since the election on 16 April, President Yoon reiterated his acceptance of the election result and pledged to "communicate more with a humbler and more flexible attitude, and be the first to listen carefully to the public sentiment."

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=16 April 2024 |title=(LEAD) Yoon vows to improve communication with people after election defeat |url=https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20240416003151315?section=national/politics |website=Yonhap News Agency |access-date=16 April 2024 |archive-date=16 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240416100010/https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20240416003151315?section=national/politics |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: According to Shin Yul, a professor of political science at Myongji University, the election results would likely lead to "extreme confrontation", stating that it "won't be easy for people to see bipartisan cooperation".

references.text: <ref name="straits-yul-rxn">{{cite news |title='Lame duck' South Korean President Yoon reels from election debacle |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/lame-duck-south-korean-president-yoon-reels-from-election-debacle |access-date=11 April 2024 |work=The Straits Times |publisher=SPH Media |date=11 April 2024 |language=en |archive-date=11 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240411081515/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/lame-duck-south-korean-president-yoon-reels-from-election-debacle |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Overall, the opposition bloc (including the Rebuilding Korea Party and New Future Party (South Korea)|New Future, which are both led by former members of the Democratic Party (South Korea, 2015)|Democratic Party and are considerably anti-Yoon) did not receive enough seats to threaten the impeachment of Yoon, which would have required a two-thirds majority, or 200 seats. They won a combined total of 189 against the government alliance and New Reform Party (South Korea)|New Reform (who are more moderately conservative and big tent) total of 111. Nevertheless, the election result, and overwhelming majority in favor of the governmental opposition, was enough to effectively block any government plans going into the future. ''The Diplomat (magazine)|The Diplomat'' described Yoon Suk-yeol as a "lame duck" for his remaining three years in office. Chae Jin-won of Humanitas College at Kyung Hee University stated that "If Yoon can't find a way to work with the opposition, there is a likelihood of impeachment, which some factions in the ruling party may comply with for the sake of their own political futures."
